menstrual.title: Menstrual phase
menstrual.description: The first day of your period marks the beginning of your menstrual cycle.

follicular.title: Follicular phase
follicular.description: This phase starts on the first day of your period and lasts until ovulation.

ovulation.title: Ovulation
ovulation.description: This is when an egg is released from your ovary.

luteal.title: Luteal phase
luteal.description: This phase begins after ovulation and ends when your next period starts.

cycleLength.title: Understanding your cycle
cycleLength.definitionText: is counted from the first day of one period to the first day of the next period.

normalRange.title: Normal range
normalRange.acogName: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)¬π
normalRange.acogSuffix: , a normal menstrual cycle typically lasts between
normalRange.variation: Most people have cycles that vary by a few days each month, which is completely normal.

irregular.title: Irregular cycles
irregular.daysRange: shorter than 21 days or longer than 35 days
irregular.descriptionSuffix: and can be caused by a variety of reasons, such as:

causes.weight: Significant weight change or intense exercise

irregular.dataNote: can cause Lunari to indicate an abnormal cycle length. Most often, this is the result of forget to log period. Tracking your cycles for at least 3-6 months will help establish a pattern.

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor?
seeDoctor.description: If your cycles are frequently abnormal in length, or/and accompanied by other concerning symptoms, it's best to talk to your health care provider. They can help you figure out the cause and suggest treatment, if necessary.

cycleLength.disclaimer: Lunari is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Lunari does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.acog: 1. Diagnosis of Abnormal Uterine Bleeding in Reproductive-Aged Women. Practice Bulletin. Number 128, July 2012. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

periodLength.title: Understanding your period
periodLength.definitionText: is counted from the first until the last day of menstrual bleeding of any volume.

normal.title: Normal period length
normal.acogName: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG)¬π
normal.acogSuffix: , a normal period length typically lasts between
normal.variation: Period length can vary from cycle to cycle, which is completely normal.

irregular.title: Irregular periods
irregular.description: Irregular periods (shorter than 2 days or longer than 7 days) might be caused by lifestyle changes, medication, stress, travel, and a few other factors that can affect hormone levels.
irregular.dataNote: could be the reason your period length is labeled prolonged or shortened. You can always correct any event of you cycle retrospectively on the calendar menu.

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor?
seeDoctor.description: If your period length is frequently abnormal in length, or/and accompanied by other concerning symptoms, it's best to talk to your health care provider. They can help you figure out the cause and suggest treatment, if necessary.

periodLength.disclaimer: Lunari is not a diagnostic tool. The information from Lunari does not replace advice from a health care provider. Always seek the advice of your doctor or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding your cycle.

references.title: References
references.acog: 1. Your First Period. American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists. FAQ for patients.

latePeriod.title: Late period
latePeriod.description: A late period can be caused by stress, changes in weight, or hormonal changes. If your period is more than a week late, consider taking a pregnancy test or consulting your healthcare provider.

whatMeans.title: What means that your period is late?
whatMeans.description: A period is generally considered late when it's more than 5-7 days past your expected date. Cycles can naturally vary by a few days each month, so occasional lateness is normal.

causes.title: Common causes
causes.stressSuffix: High stress affects hormones that regulate your cycle
causes.weightSuffix: Significant gain or loss can delay periods
causes.exerciseSuffix: Intense training can temporarily stop menstruation
causes.illnessSuffix: Being sick can throw off your cycle timing
causes.medicationsSuffix: Birth control, antibiotics, and other drugs
causes.pcosSuffix: Polycystic ovary syndrome causes irregular cycles

seeDoctor.title: When to see a doctor
seeDoctor.description: Consult a healthcare provider if your period is more than 3 months late, if you experience severe pain, or if you've had unprotected sex and could be pregnant. Sudden changes in cycle regularity also warrant a check-up.

whatToDo.title: What you can do
whatToDo.pregnancy: ‚Ä¢ Take a pregnancy test if there's any possibility
whatToDo.stress: ‚Ä¢ Manage stress through meditation, exercise, or therapy
whatToDo.weight: ‚Ä¢ Maintain a healthy weight for your body
whatToDo.track: ‚Ä¢ Track your cycles to identify patterns
whatToDo.patience: ‚Ä¢ Be patient, occasional irregularity is normal

prediction.title: How predictions work
prediction.description: Lunari predicts your next period based on your cycle history. The more data you log, the more accurate the predictions become.

nextPeriod.title: Next period prediction
nextPeriod.description: Your next period is predicted by adding your average cycle length to the start date of your most recent period.

cycleLengthCalc.title: Cycle length calculation
cycleLengthCalc.description: Lunari calculates your average cycle length using a weighted average of your last 6 cycles, a commonly used approach in cycle tracking.
cycleLengthCalc.weighting: Recent cycles have more influence on predictions than older ones. For example, most recent cycle: 100%, second most recent: 80%, third most recent: 60%, and so on.

ovulation.title: Ovulation & fertility
ovulation.description: Ovulation is predicted to occur 14 days before your next expected period. Your fertile window includes:
ovulation.fertileWindow: ‚Ä¢ 5 days before ovulation ‚Ä¢ Ovulation day ‚Ä¢ 1 day after ovulation

accuracy.title: Accuracy improves over time
accuracy.description: The more periods you track, the more accurate predictions become. With 3+ cycles, Lunari can provide personalized predictions based on your unique patterns.

privacy.title: Privacy first
privacy.description: All calculations happen locally on your device. Your period data never leaves your phone and is never shared with anyone.

prediction.disclaimer: üõéÔ∏è Remember: These are predictions based on your historical data. Every body is different, and cycles can vary naturally.
